column2: Patients who underwent colonoscopy, with findings from normal to stage 4 colorectal cancer.
column11: DDBJ Sequence Read Archive DRA006684 and DRA008156 / Paper SI /  NCBI BioProject PRJDB4176
column16: Metagenomic and metabolomic analyses reveal distinct stage-specific phenotypes of the gut microbiota in colorectal cancer
column18: Control subjects are shared with ERAWIJANTARI_GASTRIC_CANCER_2020 study (a column indicating which subjects exactly was added to the metadata)

column2: Inflammatory bowel disease patients and controls (PRISM cohort + A validation cohort).
column11: NCBI BioProject ID PRJNA400072 / Paper SI
column13: Four complimentary LC-MS methods (see Table S3)
column16: Gut microbiome structure and metabolic activity in inflammatory bowel disease
column18: The dataset includes two different cohorts: the main PRISM cohort (from Boston, USA) and a validation cohort from the Netherlands. Samples from the two cohorts can be identified by the sample name prefix.

column2: Colorectal cancer patients and controls.
column16: Faecal Microbiota, Faecal Metabolome, and Colorectal Cancer Interrelations
column18: Raw 16S data was unavailable (processed data was used instead, and taxonomy mapped to GTDB only when mapping was confident).

column2: Infants over several time points during the 1st year of life, either breast-fed, formula-fed, or experimental formula fed.
column16: Faecal microbiome and metabolome of infants fed bovine MFGM supplemented formula or standard formula with breast-fed infants as reference: a randomized controlled trial

column2: HMP2 (integrative HMP) cohort: Inflammatory bowel disease patients who were profiled several times over the course of a year.
column13: Four complimentary LC-MS methods (see Table S3)
column16: Multi-omics of the gut microbial ecosystem in inflammatory bowel diseases
column18: Only main metadata fields were selected, hundreds of additional metadata fields per sample are available in publication SI

column2: Inflammatory bowel disease patients and their first degree (healthy) relatives.
column16: A Disease-Associated Microbial and Metabolomics State in Relatives of Pediatric Inflammatory Bowel Disease Patients

column2: Longitudinal samples from healthy donors to the Broad Institute-OpenBiome Microbiome Library (BIO-ML).
column13: Four complimentary LC-MS methods (see Table S3)
column16: A library of human gut bacterial isolates paired with longitudinal multiomics data enables mechanistic microbiome research

column2: Patients who underwent colonoscopy, half of which with a history of gastrectomy for gastric cancer and no signs of gastric cancer recurrence.
column11: Paper SI / NCBI BioProject ID PRJDB7378 and PRJDB4176
column16: Influence of gastrectomy for gastric cancer treatment on faecal microbiome and metabolome profiles
column18: Control subjects are shared with YACHIDA_CRC study (a column indicating which subjects exactly was added to the metadata)

column2: Patients with advanced colorectal adenomas, colorectal cancer, and controls.
column13: Four complimentary LC-MS methods (see Table S3)
column16: Faecal Metabolomic Signatures in Colorectal Adenoma Patients Are Associated with Gut Microbiota and Early Events of Colorectal Cancer Pathogenesis

column2: Longitudinal samples (over 6 months) from patients with Irritable Bowel Syndrome and controls.
column16: Longitudinal Multi-omics Reveals Subset-Specific Mechanisms Underlying Irritable Bowel Syndrome
column18: Only main metadata fields were selected, dozens of additional metadata fields per sample are available in publication SI

column2: Children with ASD and neurotypical children as controls
column16: Differences in fecal microbial metabolites and microbiota of children with autism spectrum disorders

column2: Longitudinal samples from children at risk for T1D (DIABIMMUNE cohort).
column13: Four complimentary LC-MS methods (see Table S3)
column16: The Dynamics of the Human Infant Gut Microbiome in Development and in Progression toward Type 1 Diabetes

column2: Preterm infants followed over the first 6 months of life. Some developed late-onset sepsis or necrotizing enterocolitis.
column16: The Microbiome and Metabolome of Preterm Infant Stool Are Personalized and Not Driven by Health Outcomes, Including Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Late-Onset Sepsis

column2: Adults with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and controls.
column16: Aberrant gut microbiota alters host metabolome and impacts renal failure in humans and rodents
